review_title: A place to grow as a tutor, a professional, and a person
job_title: Peer Writing Tutor in Westminster, MD
pros: Working at McDaniel's writing center gave me a chance to grow as a professional and a person. I not only got to tutor undergraduate and graduate students, strengthening my interpersonal communication skills and collaboration abilities, but I also got to gain experience with social media, blogging, and phone use. The Writing Center is a casual, relaxed place to work and be, with free coffee for students and tutors. Most tutors work four to six hours a week. Schedules are set at the beginning of each semester, with each tutor slated to work during the same time time slots throughout the 13-week tutoring semester; however, tutors have lots of flexibility to trade shifts. Our boss, the writing center director, is kind, friendly, and supportive, and he even hosts tutor parties one or two times a semester. Ultimately, working at the Writing Center helped me make some great friends and gave me a fun, flexible, supportive place to work and give back to the McDaniel community. I'll remember my time there fondly for years to come.
cons: The Writing Center is not a place to work for students looking to work more than 5-6 hours per week, and the starting salary is minimum wage, despite the fact that unlike other minimum wage campus jobs, a tutoring job takes a semester's worth of training. My salary was lower than that of student tour guides.

pros:
Great students who are engaged and have a good attitude about learning.  They appreciate faculty efforts to abide by the practices that make us a "college that changes lives."

cons: Faculty morale is down recently because of depressed salaries and impending cuts.  This is exacerbated by the president who is constantly traveling, making many wonder what he does to actually promote the college. review_title: Good community, nice place to make things happen.
pros: Being able to get to know your colleagues and students. Developing relationships. As a small school, you can accomplish things without a huge administrative overhead, and are encouraged to be creative. Good work-life balance if you make it that way (easy to get sucked in if you let yourself, like a lot of colleges)
cons: Salaries low, but ok depending on job. Good area to live in, close to metro areas without the overhead, and reasonable cost of living, esp. if you don't mind a bit of a commute - PA only 15 mi. north. College defers a lot of maintenance.

review_title: Students are wonderful; colleagues are dedicated; adminstration clueless
pros: The students are among some of the best I have taught at 4 universities; faculty colleagues are dedicated and are passionate about teaching.
cons: Faculty and staff morale is at an all-time low.  Administrative salaries are competitive with the region while faculty and staff have had no significant increase in a decade.  Not even cost of living.  The president is constantly traveling and working on the boards of other organizations.  He has repeatedly told the staff that no one was getting salary increasing while his salary continued to increase.    The administration seems incapable of owning their mistakes or changing course.
